newsitem.title: UK: Trail of sleaze dogs Britain's Conservatives.
newsitem.headline: Trail of sleaze dogs Britain's Conservatives.

text.p: British Prime Minister John Major's government was again under fire over allegations of sleaze on Wednesday when a junior minister was forced to resign after his behaviour was slammed in a parliamentary report.
Including David Willetts, Major's government has lost nine ministers and seven senior members of parliament because of improprieties, mainly of a sexual nature, since the 1992 election.

The Standards and Privileges Committee said Willetts should not have discussed a sleaze inquiry, into ex-minister Neil Hamilton, with the chairman of a committee investigating it when he was a government "whip", or parliamentary business manager.
It said Paymaster-General Willetts had gone "beyond what should properly have taken place" and his evidence to the Standards Committee was not accurate.
The following is a list of the political casualties:
MINISTERS
December 11, 1996 - David WILLETTS resigns after criticism by a parliamentary report.
June 1996 - Rod RICHARDS, a junior Welsh Office minister, resigned after a Sunday newspaper printed allegations that the 47-year-old father of three was having an affair.
March 1995 - Robert HUGHES, a junior civil service and science minister, quit his post after admitting an affair.
Oct 1994 - Tim SMITH, junior Northern Ireland minister, resigned after admitting he failed to declare cash for putting parliamentary questions for Harrods boss Mohammed al Fayed.

Oct 1994 - Neil HAMILTON, corporate affairs minister, quit saying he needed to fight to clear his name after the allegations he had taken cash for questions and that he failed to declare favours from Fayed, including a stay in Paris Ritz.
Jan 1994 - Tim YEO, junior environment minister, resigned after fathering the child of a Tory councillor.
Jan 1994 - Earl of CAITHNESS, aviation and shipping minister, resigned after his wife's suicide.

June 1993 - Michael MATES, Northern Ireland minister, resigned after reports he gave a watch engraved with the words "Don't let the buggers get you down" to tycoon Asil Nadir, a fugitive from British justice holed up in northern Cyprus.
Sept 1992 - David MELLOR, National Heritage Secretary, quit after publicity over a free holiday and an affair with actress.
MINISTERIAL AIDES AND PARLIAMENTARY BUSINESS MANAGERS
April 1995 - Richard SPRING, a ministerial aide, stood down over newspaper allegations of a three-in-a-bed sex romp.
July 1994 - Graham RIDDICK and David TREDINNICK stood down as aides after allegations they took cash for questions.
May 1994 - Michael BROWN, a parliamentary business manager, or "whip", quit after a male student alleged they had an affair.
Feb 1994 - Hartley BOOTH resigned as a ministerial aide after admitting he "flirted" with a researcher.
Feb 1994 - Another ministerial aide, Stephen MILLIGAN, died after an auto-erotic sex experiment went wrong.
Jan 1994 - Alan DUNCAN quit as a ministerial aide after buying a cut-price council house.

Jan 1994 - David ASHBY quit as a ministerial aide after admitting sharing a bed with a man to save money on a holiday in France. Allegations of homosexuality emerged again in a divorce trial, where his Italian-born wife attacked his character.
